Policy Controls.â€„ Each use case mentioned above is covered by a policy that
enforces a certain type of training without restricting the model
architecture or training parameters. TableÂ 3 shows simple policies, where we use the high-level call runFL() to represent policies corresponding to federated training which can be unraveled to a more detailed view as in Sec.Â 3.3. The PoliFL Server requires certain
functions defined in collaboration with the third-party service, e.g.,Â training, data fetching, and aggregation. We support
scoping and thus combine multiple training methods under a single
umbrella call runFL(). We further introduce a function
get_data(data_type) that fetches corresponding data
from the participating device.

We evaluate whether the use of cascaded training is capable of improving
the performance of the model while preserving heterogeneous privacy restrictions.
For each use case, we divide the dataset of user data into groups
with distinct policies from TableÂ 3.

In this task we tested several different cases, listed in TableÂ 5. We divided users into two equal groups (Gâ€‹r1ğºsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1Gr_{1} and Gâ€‹r2ğºsubscriptğ‘Ÿ2Gr_{2}) and manipulated (a) the data access (users either contribute all their data, or exclude location and microphone) and (b) the preference of high and low privacy, with added noise Ïƒğœ\sigma of 0.01 and 0.001, respectively.
For more information about the executed policies, please refer to TableÂ 3.

The main consequence when using differential privacy is that it requires restriction on training
parameters in order to achieve desired budget. In particular, DP benefits from a larger round size and smaller number of total roundsÂ (fedlearn_dp, ). Whereas the round
size is limited by the available memory to accumulate updates from all the participants, the number of total rounds can be reduced at a cost of impacting the model performance.
Furthermore, if the training involves only part of the dataset, all users participating
in training incur higher privacy costs (see TableÂ 4 for examples on privacy budgets and its dependency on training hyperparameters and dataset size).

Due to hardware limitations, we cannot
maintain tight differential privacy guarantees and produce models that converge on an even relatively large dataset
of 80,0008000080,000 Reddit users. Achieving meaningful privacy guarantees on datasets and acceptable utility
require a large number of participants, e.g.,Â millions of users and large round size shown in
TableÂ 4 and has been empirically demonstrated by McMahanÂ et al.Â (fedlearn_dp, ).
To mitigate this problem we adopt a notion of weak differential privacyÂ (naseri2020toward, ), aiming to mimic the DP parameters, e.g.,Â clipping bound and noise distribution, proposed by McMahanÂ et al.Â (fedlearn_dp, ).

Results.â€„ The results for the two-group and three-group cascade
are shown in Fig.Â 6(a) and 6(b), respectively. Our experiments are based on the
settings shown in TableÂ 4, but using a smaller dataset.
We compare the cascading trained model (row 6) to two other models, one trained with all data but at a higher privacy (lower Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon budget, row 5)
and the other using the low privacy (higher Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon budget, row 2) group. We ignore rows 3 and 4 as they do not satisfy privacy budgets, as well as the row 1 case that is part of a combined case 5.
Following the results in TableÂ 4 (rows 5 and 6)
when two groups are combined together (e.g.,Â using the complete dataset) we run FL for twice as long.

references:
In this task we tested several different cases, listed in TableÂ 5. We divided users into two equal groups (Gâ€‹r1ğºsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1Gr_{1} and Gâ€‹r2ğºsubscriptğ‘Ÿ2Gr_{2}) and manipulated (a) the data access (users either contribute all their data, or exclude location and microphone) and (b) the preference of high and low privacy, with added noise Ïƒğœ\sigma of 0.01 and 0.001, respectively.
For more information about the executed policies, please refer to TableÂ 3.

Results.â€„ TableÂ 5 shows the performance of the user behavior modeling task in the two different cases of policy preference. Our approach for cascaded training in the example of data access-based policies was to train the group with less data first (i.e.,Â no microphone and location data) and further personalize the model with the group of richer data (i.e.,Â include all data), achieving an AUC performance of 71.1%percent71.171.1\%, a 1.13%percent1.131.13\% increase compared to a homogeneous policy that does not allow access to these sensitive data for all users (Gâ€‹r1+Gâ€‹r2ğºsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğºsubscriptğ‘Ÿ2Gr_{1}+Gr_{2}). Similar to the other two tasks, cascaded training achieved an accuracy of 70.9%, outperforming both other cases of high (68.4%) and low (69.1%) privacy preference. Note that, once again, the low privacy task had to be stopped at epoch 250 in order to keep the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon guarantee valid.
